CMS Manual System Update Department of Health & Human Services
Pub 100-06 | Chapter 4 | Section 401.1 Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Transmittal 12006 Date: August 25, 2023
Change request
I. Summary of Changes
Updates to the CMS Internet-Only Manual (IOM), Chapter 4, Section 401.1 – Exhibit 1 and Exhibit 2:
• Revised protocols for estimating allowances for uncollectible accounts
• Updated procedures for accounts receivable trending analysis
II. Changes in Manual Instructions
(REVISED) Exhibit 1: Deducted-Only One Per Row
R/N/D Chapter/Section/Title
R $4011 -Exhibit 14, Protocol engineering
R $4022 Exhibit Account
III. Funding
No additional funding will be provided by CMS.Contractors must use existing operating budgets
IV. Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs)
MACs are instructed to implement these changes For questions, contact the person listed in the Internet-Only
Manual (IOM) Change Request
Attachments
• Exhibit 1: Protocol for Estimating Allowance for Uncollectible Accounts
• Exhibit 2: Accounts Receivable Trending Analysis Procedures
V. ATTACHMENTS:
Business Requirements
Manual Instructions
Attachment - Business Requirements

Pub. 100-06 Transmittal: 1326 Date: July 29, 2025 Change Request 14102
SUBJECT: The Fiscal Year 2025 CMS Internet Only Manual (IOM) Update to Publication (Pub.) 100-06, Chapter
5, 401.1 - Exhibit 14 - Protocol for Estimating Allowance for Uncollectible Accounts and 402.2-Exhibit 22 -
Accounts Receivable Trending Analysis Procedures
EFFECTIVE DATE: August 28, 2025
IMPLEMENTATION DATE: August 28, 2025
1. SUMMARY OF CHANGES:
The purpose of this Change Request (CR) is to provide updates to the instructions in the Internet Only Manual
(IOM). Publication 100-06. Chapter 5 Financial Reporting, sections 401.1 - Exhibit 14 - Protocol for Estimating
Allowance for Uncollectible Accounts and 402.2 - Exhibit 22-Accounts Receivable Trending Analysis Procedures.
The updates include several minor clarifications
2. GENERAL INFORMATION
A. Background:
The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Internet Only Manual (IOM), Publication 100-06. Medicare
Financial Management Manual, Chapter 5. Financial Reporting, provides instructions to Medicare Administrative
Contractors (MACS) for financial reporting. This Change Request (CR) updates the instructions in the IOM as
described above.
B. Policy:
No policy is being established or changed by this CR. The updates are minor clarifications to the
Instructor
C. Provider Education:
No provider education is required
D. Other:
No additional funding will be provided by CMS: contractor activities are to be camed out within their operating
budgets

VI CONTACTS
Post-Implementation Contact(s):
Contact your Contracting Officer's Representative (COR).
VIL FUNDING
Section A: For Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACS):
The Medicare Administrative Contractor is hereby advised that this constitutes technical direction as defined in your
contract. CMS does not construe this as a change to the MAC Statement of Work. The contractor is not obligated to
incur costs in excess of the amount allotted in your contract unless and until specifically authorized by the
Contracting Officer. If the contractor considers anything provided, as described above, to be outside the current
scope of work, the contractor shall withhold performance on the part(s) in question and immediately notify the
Contracting Officer, in writing or by e-mail, and request formal directions regarding continued performance
requirements.

40114-Exhibit 14-Protocol for Estimating Allowance for Uncollectible Accounts (Ref 1326, Issued: 07-29-25:
Effective Date: 08-28-25: Implementation Date: 08-28-25)
The Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board (FASAB) recommends drawing Statement of Federal Financial
Accounting Standard Number 1 (Paragraphs 44-45) that the recorded allowance for uncollectible accounts should
be an amount that, when subtracted from the gross amount of accounts receivable, results in a net amount that is the
agency's best estimate of the amount that will actually be collected. The allowance should be re-evaluated at the end
of each fiscal year and at interim periods, as necessary, to ensure that it reflects the agency's best estimate of the net
realizable value of accounts receivable. The estimate should be based on an analysis of both individual accounts and
groups of accounts, as appropriate. The analysis should be based on historical collection experience, adjusted for
changes in current conditions, and, when appropriate, reasonable and supportable forecasts of future conditions.
Accounts that represent individual amounts, e.g., greater than $1 million, should be individually analyzed to
determine the likelihood of collection. All other accounts can be analyzed on a group basis. In addition to historical
experience, the analysis should consider such factors as the age of the receivable, the type of debtor, and other
applicable factors, including possible sources. including laws, government, state, contractors and other significant
information.
The write-off allowance for losses generally cannot be based solely on the results of individual account analysis, as
this may not provide a reasonable estimate of the amount that will actually be collected. In such cases, the agency
should use group analysis, based on historical experience and adjusted for current conditions and reasonable and
supportable forecasts.
Protocol for Estimating Allowance for Uncollectible Accounts
Medicare accounts receivable must be analyzed to determine whether each account is collectible or in order to
reduce the allowance for uncollectible accounts to the agency's best estimate of the net realizable value of accounts
receivable. The analysis should be based on both individual and group analysis, as appropriate. The analysis should
consider historical collection experience. adjusted for changes in current conditions, and, when appropriate,
reasonable and supportable forecasts of future conditions.
Medicare accounts that meet materiality thresholds are analyzed for uncollectibility on an account-by-account basis.
Group analysis should be used for all other accounts. The following are Groups-Curent examples of Groups -
Current Group 1 (Federal Non-Federal).
Sub-Group 1
1 Class Report Settlements Annuiry (Non-MSP)
2. Clean Accounts Receivable. Oracle Balances & Other Accounts Receivable (Non-MSP) Sub-Group?
Group Health Plans (Data Match Non-Data Match) MSP
2 Liability MSP
